Example: Andariel has used watering hole attacks, often with zero-day exploits, to gain initial access to victims within a specific IP range.
APT19 performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.
APT28 has compromised targets via strategic web compromise utilizing custom exploit kits.
APT32 has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.

APT37 has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware. The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims. As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.
APT38 has conducted watering holes schemes to gain initial access to victims.
Axiom has used watering hole attacks to gain access.
Bad Rabbit spread through watering holes on popular sites by injecting JavaScript into the HTML body or a .js file.
BRONZE BUTLER compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.
Bundlore has been spread through malicious advertisements on websites.
Dark Caracal leveraged a watering hole to serve up malicious code.
Darkhotel used embedded iframes on hotel login portals to redirect selected victims to download malware.
Dragonfly has compromised targets via strategic web compromise (SWC) utilizing a custom exploit kit.
Elderwood has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.
Grandoreiro has used compromised websites and Google Ads to bait victims into downloading its installer.
KARAE was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.
Lazarus Group delivered RATANKBA and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.
Leafminer has infected victims using watering holes.
Leviathan has infected victims using watering holes.
LoudMiner is typically bundled with pirated copies of Virtual Studio Technology (VST) for Windows and macOS.
Machete has distributed Machete through a fake blog website.
Magic Hound has conducted watering-hole attacks through media and magazine websites.
Patchwork has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.
PLATINUM has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.
POORAIM has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.
PROMETHIUM has used watering hole attacks to deliver malicious versions of legitimate installers.
REvil has infected victim machines through compromised websites and exploit kits.
RTM has distributed its malware via the RIG and SUNDOWN exploit kits, as well as online advertising network Yandex.Direct.
Threat Group-3390 has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.
Transparent Tribe has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with Crimson, njRAT, and other malicious tools.
Turla has infected victims using watering holes.
Windigo has distributed Windows malware via drive-by downloads.
Windshift has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: APT28 has used a variety of public exploits, including CVE 2020-0688 and CVE 2020-17144, to gain execution on vulnerable Microsoft Exchange; they have also conducted SQL injection attacks against external websites.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: APT29 has exploited CVE-2019-19781 for Citrix, CVE-2019-11510 for Pulse Secure VPNs, CVE-2018-13379 for FortiGate VPNs, and CVE-2019-9670 in Zimbra software to gain access. They have also exploited CVE-2020-0688 against the Microsoft Exchange Control Panel to regain access to a network.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: APT39 has used SQL injection for initial compromise.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: APT41 exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Axiom has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: BackdoorDiplomacy has exploited CVE-2020-5902, an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability, to drop a Linux backdoor. BackdoorDiplomacy has also exploited mis-configured Plesk servers.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: BlackTech has exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0, CVE-2017-7269, in order to establish a new HTTP or command and control (C2) server.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Blue Mockingbird has gained initial access by exploiting CVE-2019-18935, a vulnerability within Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Dragonfly has conducted SQL injection attacks, exploited vulnerabilities CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-0688 for Citrix and MS Exchange, and CVE-2018-13379 for Fortinet VPNs.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Fox Kitten has exploited known vulnerabilities in Fortinet, PulseSecure, and Palo Alto VPN appliances.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: GALLIUM exploited a publicly-facing servers including Wildfly/JBoss servers to gain access to the network.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: GOLD SOUTHFIELD has exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities for initial compromise.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: HAFNIUM has exploited CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 to compromise on-premises versions of Microsoft Exchange Server, enabling access to email accounts and installation of additional malware.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Havij is used to automate SQL injection.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Ke3chang has compromised networks by exploiting Internet-facing applications, including vulnerable Microsoft Exchange and SharePoint servers.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Kimsuky has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Magic Hound has used open-source JNDI exploit kits to leverage the Log4j (CVE-2021-44228) vulnerability.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: menuPass has leveraged vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure VPNs to hijack sessions.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Night Dragon has performed SQL injection attacks of extranet web servers to gain access.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Operation Wocao has gained initial access via vulnerable webservers.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Rocke exploited Apache Struts, Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271), and Adobe ColdFusion (CVE-2017-3066) vulnerabilities to deliver malware.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Siloscape is executed after the attacker gains initial access to a Windows container using a known vulnerability.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: SoreFang can gain access by exploiting a Sangfor SSL VPN vulnerability that allows for the placement and delivery of malicious update binaries.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: sqlmap can be used to automate exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Threat Group-3390 has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 and CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in Exchange Server.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: Volatile Cedar has targeted publicly facing web servers, with both automatic and manual vulnerability discovery.

Technique: Initial Access: T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application
Example: ZxShell has been dropped through exploitation of CVE-2011-2462, CVE-2013-3163, and CVE-2014-0322.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: APT28 has used Tor and a variety of commercial VPN services to route brute force authentication attempts.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: APT29 has used compromised identities to access networks via SSH, VPNs, and other remote access tools.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: APT41 compromised an online billing/payment service using VPN access between a third-party service provider and the targeted payment service.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Chimera has used legitimate credentials to login to an external VPN, Citrix, SSH, and other remote services.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Doki was executed through an open Docker daemon API port.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Dragonfly has used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: GALLIUM has used VPN services, including SoftEther VPN, to access and maintain persistence in victim environments.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: GOLD SOUTHFIELD has used publicly-accessible RDP and remote management and monitoring (RMM) servers to gain access to victim machines.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Hildegard was executed through an unsecure kubelet that allowed anonymous access to the victim environment.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Ke3chang has gained access through VPNs including with compromised accounts and stolen VPN certificates.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Kimsuky has used RDP to establish persistence.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Kinsing was executed in an Ubuntu container deployed via an open Docker daemon API.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Leviathan has used external remote services such as virtual private networks (VPN) to gain initial access.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Linux Rabbit attempts to gain access to the server via SSH.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Night Dragon has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: OilRig uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Operation Wocao has used stolen credentials to connect to the victim's network via VPN.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Sandworm Team has used Dropbear SSH with a hardcoded backdoor password to maintain persistence within the target network. Sandworm Team has also used VPN tunnels established in legitimate software company infrastructure to gain access to internal networks of that software company's users.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: TeamTNT has used open-source tools such as Weave Scope to target exposed Docker API ports and gain initial access to victim environments. TeamTNT has also targeted exposed kubelets for Kubernetes environments.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: TEMP.Veles has used a VPN to persist in the victim environment.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Threat Group-3390 actors look for and use VPN profiles during an operation to access the network using external VPN services. Threat Group-3390 has also obtained OWA account credentials during intrusions that it subsequently used to attempt to regain access when evicted from a victim network.

Technique: Initial Access: T1133 External Remote Services
Example: Wizard Spider has accessed victim networks by using stolen credentials to access the corporate VPN infrastructure.
DarkVishnya used Bash Bunny, Raspberry Pi, netbooks or inexpensive laptops to connect to the company’s local network.
Axiom has used spear phishing to initially compromise victims.
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has conducted malicious spam (malspam) campaigns to gain access to victim's machines.
Hikit has been spread through spear phishing.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Agent.btz drops itself onto removable media devices and creates an autorun.inf file with an instruction to run that file. When the device is inserted into another system, it opens autorun.inf and loads the malware.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: APT28 uses a tool to infect connected USB devices and transmit itself to air-gapped computers when the infected USB device is inserted.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Part of APT28's operation involved using CHOPSTICK modules to copy itself to air-gapped machines and using files written to USB sticks to transfer data and command traffic.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Conficker variants used the Windows AUTORUN feature to spread through USB propagation.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Crimson can spread across systems by infecting removable media.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Darkhotel's selective infector modifies executables stored on removable media as a method of spreading across computers.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: DustySky searches for removable media and duplicates itself onto it.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: FIN7 actors have mailed USB drives to potential victims containing malware that downloads and installs various backdoors, including in some cases for ransomware operations.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Flame contains modules to infect USB sticks and spread laterally to other Windows systems the stick is plugged into using Autorun functionality.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: H1N1 has functionality to copy itself to removable media.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Mustang Panda has used a customized PlugX variant which could spread through USB connections.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: njRAT can be configured to spread via removable drives.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: QakBot has the ability to use removable drives to spread through compromised networks.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Ramsay can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on removable drives.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: APT30 may have used the SHIPSHAPE malware to move onto air-gapped networks. SHIPSHAPE targets removable drives to spread to other systems by modifying the drive to use Autorun to execute or by hiding legitimate document files and copying an executable to the folder with the same name as the legitimate document.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Stuxnet can propagate via removable media using an autorun.inf file or the CVE-2010-2568 LNK vulnerability.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Tropic Trooper has attempted to transfer USBferry from an infected USB device by copying an Autorun function to the target machine.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Unknown Logger is capable of spreading to USB devices.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: Ursnif has copied itself to and infected removable drives for propagation.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: USBferry can copy its installer to attached USB storage devices.

Technique: Initial Access: T1091 Replication Through Removable Media
Example: USBStealer drops itself onto removable media and relies on Autorun to execute the malicious file when a user opens the removable media on another system.
Once APT28 gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.
APT29 has gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.
GOLD SOUTHFIELD has breached Managed Service Providers (MSP's) to deliver malware to MSP customers.
menuPass has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.
Sandworm Team has used dedicated network connections from one victim organization to gain unauthorized access to a separate organization.
Threat Group-3390 has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.
APT18 actors leverage legitimate credentials to log into external remote services.

APT28 has used legitimate credentials to gain initial access, maintain access, and exfiltrate data from a victim network. The group has specifically used credentials stolen through a spearphishing email to login to the DCCC network. The group has also leveraged default manufacturer's passwords to gain initial access to corporate networks via IoT devices such as a VOIP phone, printer, and video decoder.
APT29 used different compromised credentials for remote access and to move laterally.
APT33 has used valid accounts for initial access and privilege escalation.
APT39 has used stolen credentials to compromise Outlook Web Access (OWA).
APT41 used compromised credentials to log on to other systems.
Axiom has used previously compromised administrative accounts to escalate privileges.
Carbanak actors used legitimate credentials of banking employees to perform operations that sent them millions of dollars.
Chimera has used a valid account to maintain persistence via scheduled task.
Dragonfly has compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.
Dtrack used hard-coded credentials to gain access to a network share.

Adversaries can instruct Duqu to spread laterally by copying itself to shares it has enumerated and for which it has obtained legitimate credentials (via keylogging or other means). The remote host is then infected by using the compromised credentials to schedule a task on remote machines that executes the malware.
FIN10 has used stolen credentials to connect remotely to victim networks using VPNs protected with only a single factor.
FIN4 has used legitimate credentials to hijack email communications.
FIN5 has used legitimate VPN, RDP, Citrix, or VNC credentials to maintain access to a victim environment.
To move laterally on a victim network, FIN6 has used credentials stolen from various systems on which it gathered usernames and password hashes.
FIN7 has harvested valid administrative credentials for lateral movement.
FIN8 has used valid accounts for persistence and lateral movement.
Fox Kitten has used valid credentials with various services during lateral movement.
GALLIUM leveraged valid accounts to maintain access to a victim network.
Industroyer can use supplied user credentials to execute processes and stop services.
Ke3chang has used credential dumpers or stealers to obtain legitimate credentials, which they used to gain access to victim accounts.
Kinsing has used valid SSH credentials to access remote hosts.
Lazarus Group has used administrator credentials to gain access to restricted network segments.
Leviathan has obtained valid accounts to gain initial access.
Linux Rabbit acquires valid SSH accounts through brute force.
menuPass has used valid accounts including shared between Managed Service Providers and clients to move between the two environments.
Night Dragon has used compromised VPN accounts to gain access to victim systems.
OilRig has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.
Operation Wocao has used valid VPN credentials to gain initial access.
PittyTiger attempts to obtain legitimate credentials during operations.
Sandworm Team have used previously acquired legitimate credentials prior to attacks.
Some SeaDuke samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.
Silence has used compromised credentials to log on to other systems and escalate privileges.
Silent Librarian has used compromised credentials to obtain unauthorized access to online accounts.
Suckfly used legitimate account credentials that they dumped to navigate the internal victim network as though they were the legitimate account owner.
TEMP.Veles has used compromised VPN accounts.
Threat Group-3390 actors obtain legitimate credentials using a variety of methods and use them to further lateral movement on victim networks.
Wizard Spider has used valid credentials for privileged accounts with the goal of accessing domain controllers.
